Award.AwardTitle: Numerical methods for non-Newtonian fluid structure interaction problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project is focused on the stable and efficient numerical approximation of equations describing the flow of a non-Newtonian fluid interacting with an elastic structure. Such fluid flows are ubiquitous in our everyday lives, from the flow of blood in our bodies to flow in industrial processes such as pharmaceutical blending and microfluidics. This theoretical investigation will provide a solid foundation for the further development of numerical algorithms for such systems. The research project will also broaden the mathematical basis for the numerical simulation of non-Newtonian fluid flow in physically realistic settings.

The goal of this research project is the development and analysis of stable and efficient numerical schemes for non-Newtonian fluid structure interactions. There has been significant mathematical research for Newtonian fluid flow problems, but to date few investigations of non-Newtonian flows. The systems studied in this project involve coupled domains representing multi-physics behavior. This increases the numerical complexity as both stress and velocity must be resolved in the domains, and the strong interaction between the governing equations requires solution algorithms that achieve optimal convergence rates for efficiency while splitting the operators. Because of the large number of unknowns required to compute an accurate approximation of non-Newtonian (in particular viscoelastic) fluids, there is a need to develop efficient solvers for these problems. This research will contribute to the development and rigorous analysis of stability and accuracy properties of numerical methods for non-Newtonian fluid structure interactions.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project is the development and analysis of stable and efficient numerical schemes for non-Newtonian fluid structure interactions. The systems studied in this project involve coupled domains representing multi-physics behavior. This increases the numerical complexity as both stress and velocity must be resolved in the domains, and the strong interaction between the governing equations requires solution algorithms that achieve optimal convergence rates for efficiency while splitting the operators. Because of the large number of unknowns required to compute an accurate approximation of non-Newtonian (in particular viscoelastic) fluids, there is a need to develop efficient solvers for these problems. This research contributes to the development and rigorous analysis of stability and accuracy properties of numerical methods for non-Newtonian fluid structure interactions.  The research also addresses issues on decoupling schemes, and their stability, convergence and accuracy. The project results have been summarized in 10 journal papers, one book chapter, 2 Ph.D. theses and 2 master theses. 

Non-Newtonian fluid flows are ubiquitous in our everyday lives, from the flow of blood in our bodies to flow in industrial processes such as pharmaceutical blending and microfluidics. There has been significant mathematical research for Newtonian fluid flow problems, but to date few investigations of non-Newtonian flows. This theoretical investigation provides a solid foundation for the further development of numerical algorithms for such systems. The research project broadens the mathematical basis for the numerical simulation of non-Newtonian fluid flow in physically realistic settings. Two  Ph.D. students and two M.S. students were partially supported by these projects. Also two undergraduate students were involved in the projects and worked together with the Ph.D students. All Ph.D. students have co-authored at least four research papers by the time of graduation and presented their research in department seminars,  professional conferences and workshops such as SIAM annual meetings, SIAM-SEAS conferences, local student conferences, AMS sectional meetings, Finite Element Circus, etc. 



Last Modified: 09/24/2018
Modified by: Hyesuk K Lee

Because of the large number of unknowns required to compute an accurate approximation of non-Newtonian (in particular viscoelastic) fluids, there is a need to develop efficient solvers for these problems. This research contributes to the development and rigorous analysis of stability and accuracy properties of numerical methods for non-Newtonian fluid structure interactions. The research also addresses issues on decoupling schemes, and their stability, convergence and accuracy. The project results have been summarized in 10 journal papers, one book chapter, 2 Ph.D. theses and 2 master theses.
